title: I'm not the only one who thinks...
body:
BILL AND TED'S EXCELLENT ADVENTURE is one of greatest movies of all time. Jason Kottke, world reknowned blogger, also happens to agree with me.

I know I'm going to get mail about my five-star rating for this movie, but it cannot be helped. One summer when I was a kid, a friend and I watched Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure -- no joke -- every single day for a span of 2 months. I still know every line by heart, the timing, inflection, everything. If there were a Broadway production of this movie, I could slide effortlessly into the role of either Bill S. Preston, Esq. or Ted Theodore Logan, no rehearsal needed.

I'm not sure why I'm telling everyone this... I guess I just needed some vindication. I'm going to shoot Kottke an e-mail and inform him about "Bill and Ted's Excellent Musical Adventure," an amateur musical about my favorite time travelling duo (complete with soundtrack and script)!

WYLD STALLYNS!!!
author: Dan

comments.author: Matthew Martin aka Master RJ
comments.body: You're not alone. This happens to be a favorite comedy of mine (my favorite comedy is Some Like It Hot). At one point, when was eleven, it was my favorite movie and also the first DVD I ever bought (haven't got the boxed set though). But then I started watching R-rated movies and Turner Classic Movies.

comments.body: Whoa whoa whoa there Dan, now I'm not sure, but isn't it... Wyld Stallyns?

comments.author: Matthew Martin aka Master RJ
comments.body: Yep, Dan spelt it wrong. He also spelt musical wrong. I'd watch it, at least it beats "High School Musical" and almost anything by Andrew Lloyd Webber (what a hack, that Webber).

comments.author: Nate
comments.body:
It goes, "Wyld Stallions!" *air guitar riff*

You may think you can separate these things, but they are of a piece, they are parts of a whole. They are one.

I loved B&T so much that I once watched it on the movie pay-channel (even though we didn't pay for it).

So I sat there and listened to the movie and watched the srcolling lines, flashes of colour, and negative (and sometimes inverted) shadow images of the actors.
